Facilities Process Engineering Manager Intel Corporation February 2008  –  October 2010  (2 years 9 months) Operations Manager for D1C Waste Systems and manager for Oregon FSM/TD Hazmat operations; included management of collection and treatment systems and execution of bulk gas operations. Hazmat operations scope was both hazardous material and hazardous waste shipment execution in compliance with government regulations (RCRA, DOT, FFA). Managed Aloha Fab Mechanical and Process systems consisting of process chill water, critical process chill water, tool exhaust, ultra pure water (18 Mohms), and waste systems, and non-critical bulk gas systems (nitrogen, argon, hydrogen, helium). Managed both engineering and technician resources to support uninterrupted facility operations. Responsible for the ongoing physical facilities maintenance performance of facility systems against the metrics of safety, reliability/quality, environmental, and cost. Ensuring systems operate as intended without impact to microprocessor Fab. Ensure on-going improvement effort to optimize system utility efficiency. Ensuring improvement and recovery projects meet design criteria and system reliability needs. Significant Accomplishment: 1) Improved operational execution with implementation of Engineering Led and Lean Manufacturing philosophy into Waste Systems, 2) implemented an internal audit scheme for hazmat operations that improved compliance robustness that was recognized by Corporate Hazmat as a best known method, 3) implemented engineering led planning allowing for DMW capacity planning, improved statistical trend analysis of facility systems, and contingency planning for site nitrogen capacity, 4) provided leadership in two re-organization efforts resulting in minimal disruption to operations that delivered improved customer relations and implemented world class labor efficiency. Lithography Fab Process Engineering Manager Intel Corporation September 2004  –  April 2008  (3 years 8 months) Responsible for the execution of a microelectronic fabrication Lithography area; which constituted 20% of plant. Responsible for the management on the execution of Safety, Quality and Cost Effective Output for a group consisting of $40+ million of capital equipment, 17 Lithography process modules, 8 engineers, and 16 technicians. Provided technical leadership, program management, and organizational development. Led strategic initiatives to ensure business objectives consistently met. Ensured tactical responses were thorough and assisted in determining root cause analysis and solution implementation. Developed and maintained effective working relationships with related processes management and stakeholders. Provided daily updates to senior factory management on issues affecting output performance. Led team through the implementation of Lean Manufacturing philosophy. Significant Accomplishment: 1) Start-up of organization from construction to 10,000 wafer start per week capacity; 2) leader of 5 lithography technology transfers Sr. Chemical Process Lithography Engineer Intel Corporation May 1998  –  September 2004  (6 years 5 months) Responsible for tool module sustaining and continuous improvement involving: equipment troubleshooting, supervision of twenty technicians, recipe development, process improvement development and implementation, product material disposition, root cause analysis of issues and implementation of solutions to prevent reoccurrence, leadership of peers and technicians in strategic and tactical improvement teams. Obtained patent for innovative stepper jig (US Patent 6,630,988 (7Oct2003)). Responsible for Litho maintaining ISO compliance performance. Selected for international assignment to support technology transfer and new resist qualification. Focus area was Lithography steppers (4 yrs) and Lithography tracks (2 yrs). Significant Accomplishment: 1) 63% headcount reduction with the implementation of custom preventive maintenance routine; 2) achieved 21% defect reduction during leadership of fab wide defect reduction team; 3) lithography iline stepper leader of 4 technology transfers.
